newsitem.title: USA: U.S. foreign crudes subdued as arbitrage narrows.
newsitem.headline: U.S. foreign crudes subdued as arbitrage narrows.

text.p: U.S. foreign crude sellers attempted to offer expensive North Sea Brent into the U.S. Gulf, but potential buyers remained lukewarm, traders said.
A narrowing in the West Texas Intermediate/Brent arbitrage for November choked off sales possibilities.
The spread eased to 95 cents a barrel from around $1.10 a barrel, raising delivered costs for Brent crude.
"One seller showed a 15-cent premium (to WTI), but he backed off," an East Coast trader said, noting that sellers should be executing trades at 25 cents premium to break-even.
Offers for early Nov Brent were at 10 cents yesterday.
European refinery demand for distillate-rich crudes such as Oseberg also thinned availability to the U.S.
A handful of sweet crudes like Cusiana was seen, after a trader reportedly sold one cargo for mid-Oct Tuesday at a confidential price, believed near Nov WTI even fob.
Several Cusiana cargoes are still available for November, but were deemed expensive against light domestic alternatives.

Other available grades in the region included Ecopetrol's South Blend and Vasconia grades for November, and Oriente for second-half October. But traders said the U.S. government's upcoming sale of sour crude disuaded buyers from paying up.
"Once those barrels hit the market, we could see another 50 cents shaved off sour crude," a Midwest trader said.
In the U.S. after market, November Brent traded twice outright at $23.15 and $23.20 a barrel, at 100 lots apiece, firmer than London's IPE close at $23.11 a barrel.
Brent intermonth Nov/Dec pulled back to trade at 46 cents, down from the London session at 50/53 cents.
